source_sentence: 不造第二云何得造第三屋。
translation: How could I build a third house if I didn't build the second?'
A foolish man insists, saying.

source_sentence: 我不用下二必為我作上。
translation: 'I won't use the bottom two; I'll make the top one for myself.'
When people hear this, they laugh strangely.

source_sentence: 譬如世尊四輩弟子不勤修敬三寶。
translation: It's like the Bhagavān's four groups of disciples who don't diligently cultivate respect for the Three Treasures.
They're lazy and careless, and they want to pursue the fruit of the path.

source_sentence: 不欲下三果唯欲得第四阿羅漢果亦為時人之所嗤笑。
translation: Not wanting the lower three fruits but only wanting to attain the fourth arhatship would also be a source of derision for those people.

source_sentence: 如彼愚者等無有異(不依三乘次第先學大乘亦復如是故佛藏經云不先學小乘後學大乘者非佛弟子)。
translation: There's nothing different about a foolish person who doesn't first train in the great vehicle according to the order of the three vehicles. That's why the Tripiṭaka says that someone who doesn't first train in the lesser vehicle and then train in the great vehicle isn't a disciple of the Buddha.
Sharpening the sword.
The Sutra of the 100 Parables says.
"Once there was a man.
He was poor and destitute, and he worked for the king.
After many months and days, his body became weak and thin.
The king saw his kindness and gave him a dead camel.
After he got it, the poor man then skinned it.
He thought his knife was dull, so he asked for a stone to sharpen it.
He then obtains a whetstone upstairs.
He sharpened it so it would be sharp enough to come down and peel the skin off.
He goes back and forth sharpening the knife like this several times.
Later, he became increasingly distressed and couldn't go upstairs.
He hung a camel on the stairs and sharpened the knife with the stone.
That was so embarrassing that people laughed at it.
He's like a foolish man who breaks the precepts.
He takes a lot of money and property and uses it to cultivate good fortune.
They hope to be born in heaven but instead receive misfortune.
He's like hanging a camel on a high building, sharpening a sword.
They exert much effort and get little success.
He sells incense.
The Sutra of the 100 Parables says.

source_sentence: 昔有長者入海取沈水香。
translation: Once, an elderly man went into the ocean to get incense from submerged water.
It took years to accumulate a load, but he was able to get a cartload.
He went to the market to sell it.
Because it was expensive, there were no takers.
He went many days without selling it and became weary.
When he saw someone selling charcoal, he was able to sell it quickly.
He then burns it and makes charcoal.
He can't get half the price of a cartload of straight coals.
So it is with foolish people in the world.
They diligently pursue the Buddhahood with measureless methods.
Because it's difficult to attain, they then become discouraged.
They might as well set their minds on the fruit of śrāvakahood.
He'll quickly end birth and death and become an arhat.

Once upon a time, a husband and wife had three loaves of bread.
A husband and wife shared one cake each and ate the other.
The other one remained.
They made a promise together.
'If someone says this, they won't give them the cake.'

source_sentence: 既作要已為一餅故各不敢語。
translation: Now that they've made the promise, they each dare not say anything because it's one cake.

source_sentence: 須臾有賊入家偷盜取其財物。
translation: A moment later, a thief enters their home and steals their property.
All of their possessions ended up in the thief's hand.

source_sentence: 夫婦二人以先要故眼看不語。
translation: The husband and wife looked at him and didn't say anything because they wanted it first.

source_sentence: 賊見不語即其夫前侵掠其婦。
translation: When the thief sees that they don't speak, he takes the husband and plunders the wife.
When the husband sees that he doesn't say anything, he doesn't say anything either.
The woman then called the thief.
She said to her husband.

source_sentence: 云何癡人為一餅故見賊不喚。
translation: "Why would a foolish man see a thief and not call him because he wants a piece of bread?
Her husband clapped his hands and snapped at her, saying.
"Oh, maid!
My family won't give you another loaf of bread.'
People in the world don't hear that without scoffing.
Ordinary people are likewise.
They deceive themselves into appearing silent for the sake of petty fame and profit.

source_sentence: 為虛假煩惱種種惡賊之所侵掠。
translation: He's preyed upon by various evil thieves with false afflictions.
They lose their good qualities and fall into the three destinies.
They don't even have the heart to seek the supramundane path.
They only indulge in the five desires and play around with them.
Even though they experience great suffering, they don't think it's a problem.
There's no difference between a fool and another fool.
"They're afraid of women.
The Sutra of the 100 Parables says.
"Once, there was a man who married two women.
If he got close to one of them, he'd become angry with the other.
He couldn't plant it and stop it.

source_sentence: 便在二婦中間正身仰臥。
translation: He would then stand upright between the two wives and lay on his back.
It was raining heavily, and the house was leaking.
Water and dirt both fell into his eyes.
He didn't dare to get up and avoid it because he had an important precedent.
As a result, they both lost their eyesight.
Ordinary people in the world are likewise.
They become close to evil friends and engage in unlawful behavior.
They create karmic bonds and fall into the three bad destinies.
They remain in birth and death and lose the eye of wisdom.

source_sentence: 如彼愚夫為其二婦故二眼俱失。
translation: Like that foolish man who loses both eyes because of his two wives.

"Once, a man went to a woman's house.

source_sentence: 見其擣米便往其所偷米揜之。
translation: Seeing the pounded rice, he went to her house and stole some rice to cover it up.
When the woman came to see the husband, she wanted to share his conversation.
She couldn't mix the rice in her mouth.
He was ashamed of the woman, so he wouldn't throw it away.
That's why he didn't say anything.
The woman wondered why he didn't say anything.
She felt it with her hand and looked at it.
She said his mouth was swollen.
She said to her father.
"My husband was here the first time.
He suddenly got a swelling in his mouth.
He couldn't even speak.
His father then summoned a doctor to treat it.
The doctor then said.
"This disease is most serious and looks like a stone abscess.
If he cut it with a knife, it would be OK.'
He then used the knife to cut his mouth open.
Out of it came rice, and the matter was revealed.
People in the world are likewise.
They commit various bad acts that violate the precepts.
They conceal their faults and refuse to reveal them.
They're cast into hell, animals, and hungry ghosts.

source_sentence: 如彼愚人以小羞故不肯吐米。
translation: Like that foolish man who won't spit out rice because of petty shame.
He cuts his mouth with a knife to reveal his faults.

source_sentence: 若欲得意王形相汝當効之。
translation: "If you want to get the mind of the king in shape, you must give it effect.

"I'm not sick in the eyes.

source_sentence: 既得親近不解如來法王為眾生故種種方便現其短闕。
translation: Once they become close, they don't understand that the Tathāgata, the king of the Dharma, shows their shortcomings in various ways for the sake of sentient beings.

source_sentence: 遙見風吹大樹枝柯動搖上下。
translation: He sees a big tree whose branches are shaking up and down as the wind blows.

source_sentence: 愛網結心闇　　貪癡背智明
translation: 'The mind is darkened by the web of desire, and greed and folly defy the insight of wisdom.'

source_sentence: 雖蒙慧炬照　　愚昧猶目盲
translation: although illuminated by the torch of wisdom, the ignorant remain blind

source_sentence: 頑戇常不覺　　慧種未開萌
translation: stubborn and foolish, often unaware, the seeds of wisdom have not yet sprung forth

source_sentence: 自非慕高友　　何得寤神英
